column1: What is an informal definition of a tensor?
column2: An ordered set of numbers which is indexable along several axes.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What three key properties define a PyTorch tensor?
column2:
• Shape vector (dimensions/counts)
  • Data type (dtype)
  • Device placement
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: Why is using double precision (torch.float64) often discouraged in PyTorch?
column2: It is slow on most GPUs.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: Which functions are used to save and load PyTorch tensors to/from disk?
column2:
• torch.save()
  • torch.load()
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the difference between torch.tensor(np_array) and torch.from_numpy(np_array)?
column2:
FunctionBehavior
torch.tensor()Copies the data
torch.from_numpy()Shares memory (edits reflected in both)
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning numpy source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: How does the "joker" index -1 behave in x.view(-1, 5)?
column2: PyTorch automatically calculates the required dimension size based on the total number of elements.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: How can you restrict a Python script to use only a specific GPU on a multi-GPU system?
column2:
Set the environment variable: 
CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=N
where N is the GPU index."
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning cuda source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: Why should you prefer broadcasting or built-in torch operations over nested for-loops?
column2:
• Broadcasting is much faster.
  • Avoids the overhead of interpreted Python loops.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning broadcasting source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the first rule of broadcasting when two tensors have different numbers of dimensions?
column2: The smaller tensor is conceptually filled with singleton dimensions (size 1) from the left until it has the same dimensionality as the larger tensor.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning broadcasting source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What makes two tensors incompatible for broadcasting in a specific dimension?
column2: If both tensors have sizes > 1 in that dimension and those sizes are not equal.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning broadcasting source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: How is a dimension of size 1 handled during a broadcasting operation?
column2: It is conceptually replicated/copied until it matches the size of the corresponding dimension in the other tensor.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning broadcasting source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the result shape of torch.dot(a, b) for two 1D tensors of size d?
column2: A scalar (rank-0 tensor).
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning linalg source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the constraint for matrix multiplication torch.mm(A, B)?
column2:
• Input A must be (i, k) and B must be (k, l).
  • The inner dimensions must match.
  • It does not support broadcasting.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning linalg source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What does torch.bmm(A, B) perform on two 3D tensors of shape (b, i, k) and (b, k, l)?
column2: Batched matrix multiplication: it performs b independent matrix multiplications, one for each batch index.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning linalg source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the difference between torch.squeeze() and torch.unsqueeze()?
column2:
• squeeze(): Removes singleton dimensions (size 1).
  • unsqueeze(): Inserts a singleton dimension at a specified axis.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the difference between torch.transpose() and torch.permute()?
column2:
• transpose(): Swaps exactly two dimensions.
  • permute(): Reorders any number of dimensions simultaneously.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What are the six typical steps in the computational flow of a PyTorch model?
column2:
1. Define Dataset/DataLoader
  2. Define Prediction Model
  3. Define Loss
  4. Define Optimizer
  5. Initialize Parameters
  6. Loop over epochs (train/validation)
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: Why is transforms.Normalize() applied to image data during training?
column2:
• Centers data around 0.
  • Makes training outcomes more stable.
  • Gradients are more easily centered around 0.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning transforms source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: When should you use an Iterable-style Dataset instead of a Map-style Dataset?
column2: For streaming or dynamic data sources (e.g., Kafka, database queries) where a fixed index is not readily available.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning data source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the primary role of the __getitem__ method in a Map-style Dataset?
column2: It handles data loading and processing (e.g., loading an image from disk and applying transforms) for the i-th sample.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning data source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the primary role of the DataLoader in PyTorch?
column2: It aggregates individual samples from a Dataset into minibatches for parallel processing and handles shuffling.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning data source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: Why is it critical to use model.train() and model.eval() correctly?
column2: Certain layers (like BatchNorm and Dropout) behave differently in training vs. evaluation mode; using the wrong mode leads to invalid results.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1

column1: What is the purpose of the with torch.no_grad(): context manager?
column2: It disables gradient tracking, reducing memory usage and speeding up computations during validation or inference.
column3: week-2 winter-2025-2026 pytorch machine-learning source::week-2-slides-l2-pytorch-part1
